bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, November 4, 1952

div1.p: Hench inquires when the official invitations will be sent out for the dedication of Camp Lazear and suggests the names of additional individuals who should receive an invitation.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, November 4, 1952
div1.opener:
November 4, 1952
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
I have had discrete inquiries from some of those whom the Cuban Government
may be inviting to the dedication of Camp Lazear. They have heard nothing
and are wondering whether the dedication is to be held on December 3. They
must make their plans well in advance. Do you have any idea how soon the
official invitations will get out?

When I reported to the Walter Reed Memorial Association your plans for the
dedication, they expressed great interest of course. You may be hearing
from the Editor of The Military Surgeon. I believe this editor, and perhaps
others, will want to know something so that they may publicize the affair
in the American medical and lay press as there will be a great many who will
be very interested and very happy to know of the action of the Cuban Govern-
ment.

I wondered whether an invitation should go to the President of the American
Medical Association. I should have mentioned him before. Perhaps also an
invitation should go to Dr. Austin Smith, Editor of the Journal of the Ameri-
can Medical Association. I myself will be very shortly needing some official
invitation to present to our “Trip Committee” here so as to get permission to
attend the affair.

Pedro, you have enough troubles without worrying about hotel reservations for
me. I should not have bothered you with this. I have therefore written
directly to the Hotel Nacional. I fear that Mary cannot come but I am hoping
indeed to fly down for the affair.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: Pedro, the photographs of Building No. 1 just arrived. I do hope that
you saved me a generous amount of the original wood from the walls, the tongued
and grooved wood.
